learning_outcomes.description: Apply advanced principles of thermodynamics, units and dimensions, and fluid mechanics in practical situations in food engineering.
Utilize in-depth knowledge of heat and mass transfer to evaluate and enhance techniques used in food processing and preservation.
Analyze the roles of phase and state transitions, food freezing, and interfacial phenomena in influencing the structure and properties of food materials.
Evaluate separation processes, resource sustainability, and control systems, proposing improvements to enhance efficiency and sustainability in food processing.

Demonstrate advanced problem-solving skills and critical thinking by analyzing complex scenarios, performing precise calculations, and developing practical and innovative solutions in food engineering.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment will evaluate students on their theoretical knowledge from Modules 1 to 5, covering content from both lectures and tutorials.

Exam Details:

  • The mid-term exam consists of 16 questions, including:
  • 5 to 6 open-ended questions
  • The remaining questions will be numerical exercises
  • Duration: 90 minutes
  • In-Person Attendance Required:
  • Students must attend the exam in person.
  • A UQ student ID card is required for verification.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment covers Modules 1 to 12 and evaluates students on teamwork (group of 2) and their practical understanding of key course concepts.

Assessment Structure:

1.     Poster Presentation:

Students must create a poster and record an oral presentation following this structure:

  • Introduction, Experimental Setup, Main Results, Discussion, Conclusion, and References.

2.     Written Report:

  • In addition to the poster presentation, students must submit a written report providing a detailed narrative of their work.
  • The report should be a maximum of 4 A4 pages.

Main Topics & Group Work:

  • The assessment will focus on home-based experiments, introduced during Week 6 tutorials.
  • Experiments will be conducted in groups, and the final mark will be shared equally among group members.

Marking criteria:

Clarity of speech (10%): This refers to how engaging the speech is - every individual should say something.

Content (25%): This refers to the understanding of the home-made experiment and the theory behind it.

Style and layout (25%): This refers to the quality of pictures, images, layout, and flow.

Critical point of view (30%): explanation of why certain events and provide reasons and solutions. 

Reference (10%): Use of proper references.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The final examination will assess course material from Modules 6 to 12.

Exam Details:

  • The exam will be conducted on campus, and students must attend in person.
  • A UQ student ID card is required for verification.
  • The exam consists of 16 questions, including:
  • 5 to 6 open-ended questions
  • The remaining questions will be numerical exercises
  • Duration: 90 minutes

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(24 Feb - 01 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

Explanation of the following subjects: material properties, thermodynamics, mass and energy balance, fluid mechanics, heat transfer, mass transfer, psychrometry, sustainable processes, refrigeration, dehydration, and evaporation systems, sustainability, and instrument control.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
